questionContent.body:
What is the Output of given code
 [type=code]
 Node head = new Node(10)
 head.next = new Node(20)
 head.next.next = null
 System.out.println(head.next.next)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: next of the last node is null

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Slow-fast pointer technique.

questionContent.body:
What is the result
 [type=code]
 Node a = new Node(3)
 Node b = new Node(4)
 a.next = b
 b = null
 System.out.println(a.next.data)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: a.next still points to b, even if b = null

questionContent.body:
Choose correct insertion at end logic
 [type=code]
 
 Node insertEnd(Node head, int data) {
  Node temp = new Node(data)
  if (head == null) return temp
  Node curr = head
  while (curr.next != null) curr = curr.next
  curr.next = temp
  return head
 }

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: It traverses till end and adds new node.

questionContent.body:
Identify the bug
 [type=code]
 Node head = null
 head.next = new Node(2)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Cannot access next on null

questionContent.body: What is the space complexity of a singly linked list

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: One node stores one value.

questionContent.body:
What does the following recursive function do
 [type=code]
 void mystery(Node head) {
  if (head == null) return
  mystery(head.next)
  System.out.print(head.data + " ")
 }

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Due to the recursive call before printing, elements are printed in reverse order.

questionContent.body: Which of the following operations has O(1) time complexity in an array

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Insertion at End (O(1)) - For fixed-size arrays, Java allows constant-time insertion at the last index, unless resizing is required (in case of ArrayList).

questionContent.body: Which of the following is NOT a linear data structure

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Tree is not linear - Trees have hierarchical (not sequential) relationships, unlike arrays or linked lists

questionContent.body: What is a data structure

questionOptions.body: A way to store and organize data efficiently

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Data Structure - Efficient storage and organization of data using constructs like arrays, lists, stacks, etc. Java provides in-built support for many of these via collections framework.

questionContent.body: What is the time complexity of deleting the last node in a circular linked list

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: You must find the node before the last node.

questionContent.body: What is a disadvantage of a circular linked list

questionOptions.body: Cannot traverse easily using a while loop
Takes more memory than a singly linked list
More complex insertion and deletion operations

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Maintaining links carefully is more involved.

questionContent.body: What differentiates a circular linked list from a normal linked list

questionOptions.body: You cannot have the ‘next’ pointer point to null in a circular linked list
It is faster to traverse the circular linked list
In a circular linked list, each node points to the previous node instead of the next node
Head node is known in circular linked list

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: In a normal linked list, the ‘next’ pointer of the last node points to null. However, in a circular linked list, the ‘next’ pointer of the last node points to the head (first element) of the list. Every node in a circular linked list can be a starting point(head).

questionContent.body: What is the time complexity of searching for an element in a circular linked list

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: In the worst case, you have to traverse through the entire list of n elements

questionContent.body: Which of the following application makes use of a circular linked list

questionOptions.body: Undo operation in a text editor

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Generally, round robin fashion is employed to allocate CPU time to resources which makes use of the circular linked list data structure. Recursive function calls use stack data structure. Undo Operation in text editor uses doubly linked lists. Hash tables uses singly linked lists

questionContent.body: Which of the following is false about a doubly linked list

questionOptions.body: We can navigate in both the directions
It requires more space than a singly linked list
The insertion and deletion of a node take a bit longer
Implementing a doubly linked list is easier than singly linked list

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: A doubly linked list has two pointers ‘left’ and ‘right’ which enable it to traverse in either direction. Compared to singly liked list which has only a ‘next’ pointer, doubly linked list requires extra space to store this extra pointer. Every insertion and deletion requires manipulation of two pointers, hence it takes a bit longer time. Implementing doubly linked list involves setting both left and right pointers to correct nodes and takes more time than singly linked list

questionContent.body: Consider a small circular linked list. How to detect the presence of cycles in this list effectively

questionOptions.body: Keep one node as head and traverse another temp node till the end to check if its ‘next points to head
Have fast and slow pointers with the fast pointer advancing two nodes at a time and slow pointer advancing by one node at a time
Cannot determine, you have to pre-define if the list contains cycles
Circular linked list itself represents a cycle. So no new cycles cannot be generated

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Advance the pointers in such a way that the fast pointer advances two nodes at a time and slow pointer advances one node at a time and check to see if at any given instant of time if the fast pointer points to slow pointer or if the fast pointer’s ‘next’ points to the slow pointer. This is applicable for smaller lists

questionContent.body: Which of the following is false about a circular linked list

questionOptions.body: Time complexity of inserting a new node at the head of the list is O(1)
Time complexity for deleting the last node is O(n)
We can traverse the whole circular linked list by starting from any point

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Time complexity of inserting a new node at the head of the list is O(n) because you have to traverse through the list to find the tail node

questionContent.body: What is a memory efficient double linked list

questionOptions.body: Each node has only one pointer to traverse the list back and forth
The list has breakpoints for faster traversal
An auxiliary singly linked list acts as a helper list to traverse through the doubly linked list
A doubly linked list that uses bitwise AND operator for storing addresses

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Memory efficient doubly linked list has only one pointer to traverse the list back and forth. The implementation is based on pointer difference. It uses bitwise XOR operator to store the front and rear pointer addresses. Instead of storing actual memory address, every node store the XOR address of previous and next nodes

questionContent.body: Identify the correct way to traverse

questionOptions.body: Use for (int i = 0; i < head.size(); i++)

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Traverses till the end

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Head is updated to next node

solution.name: Solution 1

questionContent.body:
Identify the functions role
 [type=code]
 Node insertAtBeginning(Node head, int data) {
  Node newNode = new Node(data)
  newNode.next = head
  return newNode
 }

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: It creates a new node and places it before the head.
